docs.title: Welcome to loglibrary
docs.text:
loglibrary is the online AI reference library

Our goal is to help you find the information you need and let you learn at your own pace.

  • AI

    Looking to learn AI concepts?

    AI

  • Applications

    Working on a project?

    Applications

  • Programming

    Developing your technical skills?

    Programming

  • Computer Science

    Seeking stronger foundations?

    Computer Science

  • Math

    Want to understand the fundamentals?

    Math

  • Chronology

    Curious about the historical timeline?

    Chronology

  • Glossary

    Unclear what something means?

    Glossary

  • Help loglibrary

    Interested in supporting loglibrary?

    Help loglibrary

docs.title: Support the project
docs.text:
Our project is hosted on github, feel free to contribute!

Here are some ways you can help the loglibrary project:

docs.title: Contribute knowledge
docs.text: Add knowledge you want to see represented in the library

docs.title: Contribute an application guide
docs.text: Contributes guides for people to follow along with in Applications

docs.title: Add references
docs.text: Add references to other great sources around the internet

docs.title: Share your thoughts
docs.text: We would love to hear any and all feedback

docs.title: Artificial Intelligence (AI)
docs.text: This section covers the most important topics, concepts, and ways of thinking to help you understand how AI works.

docs.title: Agents
docs.text: Tool loops in open-ended sessions

docs.title: Computer Vision (CV)
docs.text: AI applied to modeling and detecting patterns in images

docs.title: Embeddings
docs.text:
The layers of AI models that numerically encode the semantic meaning of data

Used for classification, semantic similarity measurement, semantic search, clustering, and data visualization

docs.title: Large Language Models (LLMs)
docs.text: Using large neural networks to generate sequences of text

docs.title: Natural Language Processing (NLP)
docs.text: Modeling text as data

docs.title: Neural Networks (NNs)
docs.text:
Functions inspired by the brain that are trained to model data

Typically composed as a graph of stacked and connected layers of nodes

Density in neural networks (more connections between nodes, more spiking activations) tends to be preferred when the desire is to express a wider array of functions

Sparsity in neural networks (fewer connections between nodes, fewer spiking activations) when the desire is to improve speed and reduce memory usage

docs.title: Reinforcement Learning (RL)
docs.text: Training agents with feedback in an environment

docs.title: Transformers
docs.text: Neural networks composed of an encoder-decoder stackprimarily relying on attention

docs.title: Applications
docs.text: Practical guides for building AI applications meant for people working on professional or personal projects

docs.title: Customer Segmentation
docs.text:
Identifying customer segments.

Cluster tabular data, embeddings

docs.title: Document Analysis
docs.text:
Processing and analyzing documents.

cluster NLP

docs.title: Fraud Detection
docs.text:
Identifying fraudulent transactions and activities.

tabluar data classifier

docs.title: Manufacturing Inspection
docs.text:
Detecting outliers from a camera feed in a manufacturing plant.

Computer vision classifier

docs.title: Photoshoots Style Search
docs.text: Use text and/or images to query the most similar matches from a photshoot archive

docs.title: Chronology
docs.text: This should give you a sense of the historical events that have led to the current moment

docs.title: 1600s
docs.text: Mathematical, scientific, and philosophical foundations.

docs.title: Leibniz writes Preface to the general science
1700s
docs.text: Mathematical, scientific, and philosophical foundations.

docs.title: 1800s
docs.text: Mathematical, scientific, and philosophical foundations.

docs.title: Menabrea and Lovelace publish A sketch of the analytical engine invented by Charles Babbage
Boole publishes An investigation of the laws of thought
C. S. Peirce publishes "Logical Machines, Am J. Psych. 1, p. 165"
1900s
docs.text:
The invention of computing machines

The science of information theory

The development of programming, personal computers, and the internet.

docs.title: Hilbert, Mathematical problems
docs.text: These include the question of whether all mathematical truths can be arrived at computationally (without using those words at the time)

docs.title: Markov investigates the statistics of language
docs.text: A. A. Markov gives a lecture titled An Example of Statistical Investigation of the Text Eugene Onegin Concerning the Connection of Samples in Chains

docs.title: Turing, "On computable numbers, with an application to the Entscheidungsproblem"
docs.text: This refutes Hilbert's question posed in 1900

docs.title: Aiken writes the Proposed automatic calculating machine
Shannon, A symbolic analysis of relays and switching circuits
McCulloch and Pitts, A logical calculus of the ideas immanent in nervous activity
von Neumann writes the First draft of a report on the EDVAC
Shannon, A mathematical theory of communication
docs.text: This is typically considered the first proper paper in the field of Information Theory.

docs.title: von Neumann, The general and logical theory of automata
McCulloch, The brain as a computing machine
Hamming, Error detecting and error correcting codes
Shannon, Programming a computer for playing chess
Kleene, Representation of events in nerve nets and finite automata
Hopper, The education of a computer
McCarthy, Minsky, Rochester, and Shannon propose the Dartmouth summer institute on artifical intelligence
Chomsky, Three Models for the Description of Language
Rosenblatt creates The perceptron: A probabilistic model for information storage and organization in the brain
Baran, Reliable digital communications systems utilizing unreliable network repeater nodes
Gale & Shapley, College admissions and the stability of marriage
Hartmanis and Stearns, On the computational complexity of algorithms
Naur, Revised report on the algorithmic language ALGOL 60
Sutherland creates "Sketchpad, a man-machine communication system"
Amdahl et al., Architecture of the IBM System/360
Cooley and Tukey, An algorithm for the machine calculation of complex Fourier series
Knuth, On the translation of languages from left to right
Moore, Cramming more components onto integrated circuits
Weizenbaum creates ELIZA -- A computer program for the study of natural langauage communication between man and machine
Blum, A machine-independent theory of the complexity of recursive functions
R. Floyd, Assigning meanings to programs
Hoare, An axiomatic basis for computer programming
Codd, A relational model for large shared data banks
Earley, An efficient context-free parsing algorithm
Engelbart, Intellectual implications of multi-access computer networks
Licklider and Taylor, The computer as a communication device
Scott, Outline of a mathematical theory of computation
Cook, The complexity of theorem-proving procedures
Scott and Strachey, Toward a mathematical semantics of programming languages
Spärck Jones, A statistical interpretation of term specificity and its application in retrieval
Blum, Floyd, Pratt, Rivest, and Tarjan, Time bounds for selection
Liskov and Zilles, Programming with abstract data types
Ritchie and Thompson, The UNIX time-sharing system
Allen and Cocke, A program data flow analysis procedure
D. Denning, A lattice model of secure information flow
Diffie & Hellman, New Directions in Cryptography
Metcalfe and Boggs, Ethernet: Distributed Packet switching for local computer networks
Liskov et al., Abstraction mechanisms in CLU
Lamport, "Time, clocks, and the ordering of events in a distributed system"
Rivest, Shamir, and Adleman, A method for obtaining digital signatures and public-key cryptosystems
Carter and Wegman, Universal classes of hash functions
Demillo, Lipton, and Perlis, Social processes and proofs of theorems and programs

docs.text: The development of machine learning in the context of big data.
Deep learning, computer vision, and language modeling.

docs.title: DeepMind is founded by Demis Hassabis
2020 - Present
docs.text: Large language models and general purpose AI agents

docs.title: Anthropic is founded
docs.text: Anthropic was founded as a disgruntled faction of leaders and researchers from OpenAI with a $480m gift from Sam Bankman Fried

docs.title: Past - 1600s
docs.text: Mathematical, scientific, and philosophical foundations.

docs.title: Computer Science (CS)
docs.text: The science and engineering of using machines to operate with information

docs.title: Computational Complexity
docs.text: The complexity of algorithms, runtime estimation, big O notation

docs.title: Formal Grammar
docs.text: Simple rules can yield rich language generation

docs.title: Information Theory
docs.text: Bits, entropy

docs.title: State Machines
docs.text: Automata

docs.title: Turing Machines
docs.text: Computability, recursive functions

docs.title: Agent
docs.text: A system that takes actions in an environment.

docs.title: Attention
docs.text: Mechanism that lets models focus on specific parts of input.

docs.title: Autoregression
docs.text: Predicting next values based on previous ones.

docs.title: Backpropagation
docs.text: Algorithm that trains neural networks by adjusting weights.

docs.title: Classification
docs.text: Sorting data into categories.

docs.title: Convolution
docs.text: Operation that combines signals.

docs.title: Decoder
docs.text: Converts encoded data back to output.

docs.title: Deep Learning
docs.text: Machine learning with many-layered neural networks.

docs.title: Encoder
docs.text: Compresses input data into a representation.

docs.title: Entropy
docs.text: Measure of uncertainty in data.

docs.title: Feature
docs.text: A measurable property of data. Typically corresponds to the most important or useful aspects of a model that can be directly captured in data and trained on for modeling.

docs.title: Gradient
docs.text: Direction of steepest increase in a function.

docs.title: Hyperparameter
docs.text: Settings that can be chosen when running a process, for exmaple when training a model.

docs.title: Inference
docs.text: Running a trained model to generate outputs.

docs.title: Loss Function
docs.text: Measures how wrong a model's predictions are.

docs.title: Matrix
docs.text: Grid of values arranged in rows and columns for representing data and transformations.

docs.title: Neural Network
docs.text: Network of connected parameters trained to model data.

docs.title: Overfitting
docs.text: When a model memorizes training data too well and fails to make correct predictions on new data.

docs.title: Precision
docs.text: Fraction of predictions that are correct.

docs.title: Probability
docs.text: How likely something is to happen between 0% and 100%.

docs.title: Recall
docs.text: Fraction of relevant items that were found.

docs.title: Regression
docs.text: Predicting continuous numbers.

docs.title: Regularization
docs.text: Techniques to prevent overfitting.

docs.title: Reinforcement Learning
docs.text: Learning through trial and error with rewards in an environment.

docs.title: Supervised Learning
docs.text: Learning from labeled examples.

docs.title: Tensor
docs.text: Multi-dimensional array of numbers.

docs.title: Token
docs.text: Basic unit of sequences (for example, in language modeling, a token is either a small word, a part of word, or some other small sequence of text characters).

docs.title: Transformer
docs.text: Neural network architecture using attention in an encoder-decoder stack.

docs.title: Unsupervised Learning
docs.text: Finding patterns in data without labels.

docs.title: Weight
docs.text: Parameter in a neural network that determines the strength of an edge (connection between nodes) in the network.

docs.title: Math
docs.text: The fundamental math concepts that underpin AI

docs.title: Programming
docs.text: A variety of paths to write programs that use AI

docs.title: APIs
docs.text: Making basic API calls to access services and AI models

docs.text: Web app programming
